snippet: “Trouble With the Curve” is the anti-“Moneyball.” The old-time scouts from that earlier film, mocked for their superstitions about “intangibles” and “instincts,” get their revenge this time around.

headline.main: Rooting for One Player in Baseball Politics: Dad
headline.print_headline: Rooting for One Player in Baseball Politics: Dad

snippet: A Republican bill to provide permanent resident visas for foreigners who graduate from American universities with advanced degrees in science and technology failed to pass the House on Thursday.
abstract: Republican bill to provide permanent resident visas for foreigners who graduate from American universities with advanced degrees in science and technology fails to pass the House, a setback for technology companies that had strongly supported it.

headline.main: Bill to Keep Graduates in U.S. Fails in the House
headline.print_headline: Bill to Keep Graduates In U.S. Fails In the House

snippet: Retailers have been worried that displaying the new Kindles will encourage customers to browse in stores and then buy from online competitors instead, analysts said.
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores says it is dropping Amazon's Kindle tablets and e-readers, a sign of how seriously it views Amazon as a competitor in the consumer goods market; retailer will still sell similar devices from other companies; Amazon's line offers only marginal profits for retailers.

headline.main: Wal-Mart Is Deleting the Kindle From Stores
headline.print_headline: Wal-Mart Is Deleting The Kindle From Stores

byline.original: By STEPHANIE CLIFFORD and JULIE BOSMAN

snippet: After Apple’s maps service in its new iOS 6 operating system was greeted with widespread criticism, the company said Thursday that it was working hard to improve the technology.
abstract: After Apple’s maps service in its new iOS 6 operating system was greeted with widespread criticism, the company said Thursday that it was working hard to improve the technology.

headline.main: Apple on Its iOS 6 Maps: Things Can Only Get Better

snippet: The former president and executive vice president of AU Optronics were each sentenced to three years in prison for their roles in a global LCD screen price-fixing conspiracy.
abstract: Taiwanese company AU Optronics is fined $500 million for its participation in a global LCD screen price-fixing conspiracy; former president Hsuan Bin Chen and executive vice president Hui Hsiung are each sentenced to three years in prison for their roles.

headline.main: Taiwan Company Fined $500 Million for Price-Fixing
headline.print_headline: Taiwan Company Fined $500 Million for Price-Fixing

snippet: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Thursday's selection includes an unsettlingly eerie video from a game called Bad Trip, many flaws found in Apple's new map app and why it's ...
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Thursday's selection includes an unsettlingly eerie video from a game called Bad Trip, many flaws found in Apple's new map app and why it's so hard to get good Wi-Fi at 36,000 feet.

headline.main: Today's Scuttlebot: Bad Apple Maps and Wi-Fi on Planes

snippet: Pandora, with 55 monthly users, is a leader in Internet radio. But it wouldn't take much for a behemoth like Apple to become a player in the field.
abstract: Pandora, with 55 monthly users, is a leader in Internet radio. But it wouldn't take much for a behemoth like Apple to become a player in the field.

headline.main: Pandora Keeps Growing, but Apple's Plans Add to the Uncertainty
